decision.reasoning:
At 58.1% the market is pricing Seattle as a fairly solid favorite. The hard-data snippets we have don‚Äôt support that big of a gap:

- **Patriots offense generates explosives at an elite rate**: ESPN notes New England is **league-best in explosive creation rate (13.6%)**. In a single game, explosive plays are disproportionately valuable (they swing win probability more than steady efficiency).
- **Patriots playoff profile looks ‚Äútraveling defense + game control‚Äù**: their playoff wins include **16-3** and **10-7**, implying they can win even when variance is low and possessions are limited‚Äîexactly the kind of profile that keeps underdogs live.
- **Seattle‚Äôs best argument is explosiveness too**: Seahawks‚Äô **explosive-play differential (4.7 pp) best in NFL**. That‚Äôs real, but it also means the market may be overpaying for the ‚Äúmore explosive team‚Äù narrative when New England is also elite in that same high-leverage dimension.
- **Maye‚Äôs aggressiveness adds volatility, which favors the underdog price**: Ringer notes **17.3% tight-window throw rate (4th-highest)**. Yes, that can create negative plays, but it also raises ceiling outcomes‚Äîgood for a team priced at **41.9%**.

Net: I don‚Äôt see enough in the provided stats to justify Seattle as high as 58%. My rough fair line is closer to ~52‚Äì55% Seahawks, which makes **NO** (Patriots) meaningfully +EV at 41.9%.

With no web/search, I‚Äôm limited to broad historical priors rather than 2025-season strength. Historically, the Patriots have been one of the NFL‚Äôs most consistently ‚Äúhigh-floor‚Äù organizations over the past few decades (coaching/discipline/game-planning), while the Seahawks have had peaks (including a Super Bowl win) but more variance. In the one high-salience direct Super Bowl memory (Seahawks vs Patriots), New England won a tight game‚Äîsuggesting a slight ‚Äúbig-game execution‚Äù prior for the Patriots, but that‚Äôs very dated and roster-dependent.

Crucially, the fact that BOTH teams are in Super Bowl LX already implies they‚Äôre elite in this season‚Äôs context; without any current efficiency metrics, injuries, QB advantage, or coaching edges for 2025, the matchup should be close to 50/50. The market at 48.9% Seahawks is essentially a coin flip, and I don‚Äôt have enough non-market information in this blind round to justify a big 30‚Äì50% bankroll swing in either direction. My current position is also close to hedged (YES and NO both large), so there‚Äôs no urgent exposure problem to correct.

decision.reasoning:
Seeing everyone‚Äôs reasoning mostly reinforces that the *current* 50.7% Seahawks price is badly misaligned with the best ‚Äúhard‚Äù aggregate signal we have: the **betting market**.

Key points that persuaded me:
- **Seattle -4.5 / ML ~ -230** is a very strong anchor. Even after de-vig, that typically maps to roughly **~65‚Äì68% Seattle** (ballpark). A 50.7% market implies essentially a coin flip, which would be closer to pick‚Äôem / ~-110 each side, not -230.
- The **FPI/DVOA-style strength gap** cited repeatedly (SEA #1 overall/defense; NE ~top-10 overall) supports Seattle being a *clear* favorite, even if those models alone might land more in the **~58‚Äì62%** range. Combine that with the closing-line/market-implied info and I still get well above 50.7%.

What didn‚Äôt persuade me much:
- The contrarian ‚ÄúPats value‚Äù cases lean heavily on narrative/micro-matchups (explosives allowed in one game, Maye deep ball vs shells, ‚Äúreverse line move‚Äù talk). Those can matter, but they‚Äôre noisier and less predictive than a strong consensus spread/ML.
- Injury updates (Maye shoulder full, Darnold oblique) push slightly toward NE relative to peak SEA takes, but not enough to drag Seattle anywhere near 51%.

Net: my fair probability is still around **~63‚Äì66% Seahawks**, making YES meaningfully +EV at 50.7%. Given my near-flat current exposure, I want to swing net long YES aggressively.

- **Seattle -4.5 / ML ~ -230** is a very strong anchor. Even after de-vig, that typically maps to roughly **~65‚Äì68% Seattle** (ballpark). A 50.7% market implies essentially a coin flip, which would be closer to pick‚Äôem / ~-110 each side, not -230.
- The **FPI/DVOA-style strength gap** cited repeatedly (SEA #1 overall/defense; NE ~top-10 overall) supports Seattle being a *clear* favorite, even if those models alone might land more in the **~58‚Äì62%** range. Combine that with the closing-line/market-implied info and I still get well above 50.7%.

What didn‚Äôt persuade me much:
- The contrarian ‚ÄúPats value‚Äù cases lean heavily on narrative/micro-matchups (explosives allowed in one game, Maye deep ball vs shells, ‚Äúreverse line move‚Äù talk). Those can matter, but they‚Äôre noisier and less predictive than a strong consensus spread/ML.
- Injury updates (Maye shoulder full, Darnold oblique) push slightly toward NE relative to peak SEA takes, but not enough to drag Seattle anywhere near 51%.

Net: my fair probability is still around **~63‚Äì66% Seahawks**, making YES meaningfully +EV at 50.7%. Given my near-flat current exposure, I want to swing net long YES aggressively.
</reasoning>

results.snippet: Seahawks: Seattle had perfect attendance at practice, but did have several players limited: Quarterback Sam Darnold (oblique), offensive tackle Charles Cross (foot), safety Nick Emmanwori (ankle), offensive tackle Josh Jones (ankle, knee), linebacker Demarcus Lawrence (rest), fullback Robbie Ouzts (neck), receiver Jaxon Smith-Njigba (rest), and defensive end Leonard Williams (rest). Patriots: Linebacker Robert Spillane (ankle) did not practice on Wednesday due to an ankle injury. However, he did tell the Boston Herald earlier in the day that he's "100% confident" that he'll be able to play in Super Bowl LX. Meanwhile, linebacker Harold Landry (knee) and offensive tackle Thayer Munford Jr. were both limited with knee injuries. Maybe the most important development on the injury front for New England comes at quarterback as the team listed Drake Maye (right shoulder) as a full participant.

decision.reasoning:
The only truly market-moving items here are the QB health confirmations: Maye trending fully healthy (bullish Patriots) while Seattle‚Äôs QB carries a potentially performance-limiting oblique tag (bearish Seahawks). QB availability/efficiency drives win probability more than marginal roster elevations at RB, and the weather update is basically neutral unless wind/rain firm up.

Net: this bundle should push probability away from Seattle. The market may have partially priced ‚ÄúMaye likely plays,‚Äù but ‚Äúfull practice week + set to start‚Äù plus Seattle QB limitation is incremental, asymmetric information that should still move the true odds toward New England.
